makers.displaydate: 1484–1551; born Cortine in Valdibiana Montaperti, Italy; died Siena, Italy
makers.displaymaker: Domenico Beccafumi, 1484–1551; born Cortine in Valdibiana Montaperti, Italy; died Siena, Italy

texts.textentryhtml:
Beccafumi was a highly individual and inventive artist who developed an independent style inspired by a variety of sources while working almost exclusively in Siena during the first half of the sixteenth century. The two oil sketches on the left demonstrate his fluid technique and subtle manipulation of light and shade to create lively head studies. The dark background accentuates these effects, intensifying the appearance of small highlights. These sheets belong to a group of twenty-three surviving works closely related in date and style to his vibrant frescoes in the Palazzo Pubblico in Siena, a commission awarded to him in 1529.
 
The painting on the right, dating from the last decade of Beccafumi’s life, represents another example of the artist’s manner of freely employing thinly applied layers of pigment. The colorful, unfinished work reveals in several sections his preliminary sketch, or underdrawing, made on the ground of the painting. These areas help to reinforce our understanding of the importance of drawing in the evolution of Beccafumi’s painted compositions. In this case, the incomplete panel elucidates the entire process, from the initial rendering of the design on the support through the intermediate and later stages of its execution.
Charles Fairfax Murray (1849–1919); Meatyard, London; purchased in 1922 by Dan Fellows Platt, stamp (l. 750a) verso, lower center on mount, in blue.

Made from life, these oil sketches demonstrate Beccafumi’s fluid technique and subtle manipulation of light and shade. The dark ground accentuates the chromatic modeling, intensifying the appearance of small highlights throughout the swiftly brushed forms. Both sheets belong to a group of twenty-three surviving head studies, which are closely related to figures in Beccafumi’s vibrant historical frescoes in the Palazzo Pubblico in Siena, a commission awarded to him in 1529.
